{{More footnotes|date=September 2011}}
'''Rubin "Rube" Lacey''' (January 2, 1902 – 1969) was an [[United States|American]] [[country blues]] musician, who played guitar and was a singer and songwriter. 

Lacey was born in Pelahatchie, [[Mississippi]], [[United States]],<ref name="Trail">{{cite web |url=http://www.thebluestrail.com/artists/mus_rl.htm |title=Rubin Lacey |author= |date= |work= |publisher=Thebluestrail.com |accessdate=November 18, 2011}}</ref> and learned guitar in his teens from an older performer, George Hendrix. Working out of the [[Jackson, Mississippi|Jackson area]] in the [[Mississippi Delta]], he became one of the state's most popular blues singers. His [[bottleneck]] style inspired that of the better known performer [[Son House]].<ref name="Trail"/> In 1927, he recorded four songs for [[Columbia Records]] in [[Memphis, Tennessee]], though none were released and the masters do not survive.

In 1928, Lacey recorded two tunes, "Mississippi Jail House Groan" and "Ham Hound Cave", for [[Paramount Records]], which constitutes his recorded legacy.<ref name="Trail"/> Four years later he became a [[Minister (Christianity)|minister]], and was later found living in [[Lancaster, California]] by blues researcher, David Evans. He died there on November 14, 1969.<ref name="Trail"/>
